page.title: 02Pollution
page.content: The raw, unsreened effluent from the town of Camborne is discharged into the sea some 300 yards from the base of the cliffs. Rough seas quickly break down the solid materials, but in periods of calm, faecal material and other solids are to be found in coves and on beaches in the area. In one instance, harmful bacteria was found to be thriving on the shoreline four days after being deposited there by a storm. Mine waste also affects the valley bottom of the Red River at Camborne Coombe, where centuries of deposition of sand from mining operations have left the soil contaminated with toxic substances. Weathering has leached this out of the top 6" (15 cm) but little will grow below this depth.
